definition: The chronological study of technological development and change over time, examination of how technology varies across different regions and cultures, and accounts of individuals whose contributions have significantly shaped technological progress, providing contextual understanding of how technology evolves within specific temporal, spatial, and personal frameworks.

Label: Medicine and health
definition: The applied science and practice concerned with maintaining and restoring human health through the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and management of disease and injury, encompassing the study of human anatomy and physiology, clinical procedures, pharmacology, surgical interventions, and specialized care across the human lifespan from pediatrics to geriatrics.

Label: Medicine and health
definition: The applied science and practice concerned with maintaining and restoring human health through the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and management of disease and injury, encompassing the study of human anatomy and physiology, clinical procedures, pharmacology, surgical interventions, and specialized care across the human lifespan from pediatrics to geriatrics.

Label: Human anatomy, cytology, histology
definition: The scientific study of the structure of the human body at multiple levels of organization, encompassing gross anatomy (the study of organs and organ systems visible to the naked eye), histology (the microscopic study of tissues), and cytology (the microscopic study of individual cells, including their structure, function, and pathology).

Label: Human physiology
definition: The scientific study of the normal functions and mechanisms of the human body's systems, organs, cells, and biomolecules, focusing on how these components work together to maintain homeostasis, respond to stimuli, and support life processes such as metabolism, respiration, circulation, and neural signaling.

Label: Personal health and safety
definition: The principles and practices individuals employ to maintain and improve their own physical and mental well-being, prevent illness and injury, and ensure a safe living environment, encompassing areas such as nutrition, exercise, hygiene, stress management, first aid, and accident prevention in daily activities.

Label: Forensic medicine; incidence of injuries, wounds, disease; public preventive medicine
definition: The application of medical knowledge to legal matters, including the investigation of death, injury, and disease for judicial purposes, coupled with the epidemiological study of the occurrence and distribution of health events in populations, and the organized efforts of society to prevent disease, prolong life, and promote health through community-wide interventions.

Label: Pharmacology and therapeutics
definition: The scientific study of drugs and their interactions with living systems, encompassing the sources, chemical properties, biological effects, and mechanisms of action of pharmaceutical substances, and the application of this knowledge to the treatment of disease through the selection, dosing, and monitoring of medications for individual patients.

Label: Diseases
definition: The study of abnormal conditions that impair the normal functioning of the human body, including their causes (etiology), mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural changes (morphology), clinical manifestations, progression, and outcomes, covering infectious, genetic, metabolic, degenerative, and environmental disorders.

Label: Surgery, regional medicine, dentistry, ophthalmology, otology, audiology
definition: The branch of medicine that employs operative manual and instrumental techniques to investigate or treat pathological conditions such as disease or injury, along with specialized fields focusing on specific anatomical regions or organ systems: surgery (operative treatment), regional medicine (conditions of specific body areas), dentistry (oral health), ophthalmology (eye diseases), otology (ear diseases), and audiology (hearing disorders).

Label: Gynecology, obstetrics, pediatrics, geriatrics
definition: Specialized medical fields focused on distinct stages and aspects of the human lifespan and reproductive health: gynecology (female reproductive system health), obstetrics (pregnancy, childbirth, and postpartum care), pediatrics (medical care of infants, children, and adolescents), and geriatrics (healthcare for elderly adults, emphasizing the management of chronic conditions and functional decline associated with aging).

Label: Engineering
definition: The branch of science and technology concerned with the design, building, and use of engines, machines, and structures. Restricted to specific engineering disciplines including Civil, Mechanical, Electrical, Mining, and Nautical engineering. Distinct from Chemical Engineering (660) and general Technology (600).

Label: Engineering and applied operations
definition: The branch of science and technology concerned with the design, building, and use of engines, machines, and structures. Restricted to specific engineering disciplines including Civil, Mechanical, Electrical, Mining, and Nautical engineering. Distinct from Chemical Engineering (660) and general Technology (600).

Label: Applied physics
definition: The branch of physics that focuses on developing practical applications and technologies based on physical principles, bridging fundamental scientific discoveries with engineering solutions in areas such as materials science, optics, electronics, and nanotechnology to solve real-world problems.

Label: Mining and related operations
definition: The engineering field concerned with the extraction, processing, and management of mineral resources from the earth, involving geological assessment, mine design, excavation techniques, mineral processing, environmental management, and safety systems for economically viable resource recovery.

Label: Military and nautical engineering
definition: The specialized engineering discipline focused on designing, developing, and maintaining military systems and naval vessels, encompassing weapons systems, defense structures, ship architecture, propulsion systems, and maritime technologies for national security and naval operations.

Label: Civil engineering
definition: The engineering profession dedicated to designing, constructing, and maintaining the physical and naturally built environment, including public works such as roads, bridges, dams, buildings, water supply systems, and transportation networks that form society's foundational infrastructure.

Label: Engineering of railroads, roads
definition: The specialized engineering domain focused on planning, designing, constructing, and maintaining transportation corridors, including railway systems, highways, and road networks, with emphasis on route selection, structural design, materials science, traffic flow optimization, and transportation safety.

Label: Hydraulic engineering
definition: The engineering specialty concerned with the flow and conveyance of fluids, primarily water, through the design and construction of hydraulic structures such as dams, canals, pipelines, pumps, turbines, and flood control systems for water resource management and energy generation.

Label: Sanitary engineering
definition: The engineering field focused on protecting public health through the design and implementation of systems for clean water supply, wastewater treatment, solid waste management, and pollution control, ensuring environmental sanitation and disease prevention in communities.

Label: Other branches of engineering
definition: Engineering disciplines not specifically enumerated in this classification but falling within the broader scope of applied operations, including emerging fields, interdisciplinary specialties, and established branches such as mechanical, electrical, chemical, aerospace, biomedical, and environmental engineering that apply scientific principles to practical problem-solving.

Label: Agriculture
definition: The integrated science, art, and practice of cultivating plants and rearing animals for food, fiber, medicinal products, and other materials essential to human sustenance and development, encompassing systematic approaches to crop production, livestock management, soil science, pest control, forestry, horticulture, and sustainable resource management to ensure food security, economic viability, and environmental stewardship.

Label: Agriculture and related technologies
definition: The integrated science, art, and practice of cultivating plants and rearing animals for food, fiber, medicinal products, and other materials essential to human sustenance and development, encompassing systematic approaches to crop production, livestock management, soil science, pest control, forestry, horticulture, and sustainable resource management to ensure food security, economic viability, and environmental stewardship.

Label: Specific techniques; apparatus, equipment, materials
definition: The specialized methods, tools, machinery, and substances employed in agricultural operations, including precision farming technologies, irrigation systems, harvesting equipment, soil amendments, fertilizers, pesticides, and innovative materials designed to enhance productivity, efficiency, and sustainability in plant cultivation and animal rearing.

Label: Plant injuries, diseases, pests
definition: The study and management of biotic and abiotic factors that cause harm to cultivated plants, encompassing plant pathology (fungal, bacterial, and viral diseases), entomology (insect pests and beneficial insects), weed science, and physiological disorders caused by environmental stresses, with emphasis on diagnosis, prevention, and control strategies to protect crop health and yield.

Label: Field and plantation crops
definition: The cultivation of staple food crops, industrial raw materials, and commercial commodities grown extensively in open fields or large-scale plantations, including cereals (wheat, rice, maize), legumes, oilseeds, fiber crops (cotton, jute), sugarcane, coffee, tea, rubber, and other cash crops managed through mechanized farming systems for bulk production.

Label: Orchards, fruits, forestry
definition: The cultivation and management of perennial woody plants for fruit production in orchards (apples, citrus, stone fruits) and the science of forestry involving the sustainable cultivation, conservation, and utilization of forest trees for timber, pulp, ecosystem services, and non-timber forest products, integrating arboriculture, silviculture, and agroforestry practices.

Label: Garden crops (horticulture)
definition: The intensive cultivation of plants for aesthetic, nutritional, and recreational purposes, encompassing vegetable gardening, floriculture (ornamental flowers), landscape horticulture, nursery production of plants, and the science of growing fruits, vegetables, herbs, and ornamental plants in controlled or small-scale environments through specialized techniques like greenhouse management and hydroponics.

Label: Animal husbandry
definition: The science and practice of breeding, raising, and managing domesticated animals for meat, milk, eggs, wool, leather, labor, and other products, including livestock nutrition, genetics, housing, health care, reproduction, and welfare standards for cattle, poultry, swine, sheep, goats, and other farm animals.

Label: Processing dairy and related products
definition: The technological processes involved in converting raw milk from animals into consumable and preservable dairy products, including pasteurization, homogenization, fermentation, cheese-making, yogurt production, butter churning, ice cream manufacturing, and the development of value-added products while ensuring food safety, quality control, and nutritional preservation.

Label: Insect culture
definition: The controlled rearing and utilization of insects for agricultural, industrial, and ecological purposes, including apiculture (beekeeping for honey and pollination), sericulture (silkworm cultivation for silk production), biocontrol agent propagation, edible insect farming, and research applications in genetics, behavior, and sustainable resource production.

Label: Hunting, fishing, conservation, related technologies
definition: The practices and technologies associated with harvesting wild animal and aquatic resources through hunting and fishing, integrated with conservation biology, wildlife management, habitat preservation, sustainable harvesting techniques, aquaculture development, and the application of ecological principles to maintain biodiversity and ecosystem health while supporting human needs.

Label: Home and family management
definition: The systematic application of organizational principles and domestic skills to coordinate household operations, encompassing food preparation, housing maintenance, interior design, clothing care, child rearing, and family care, with the objective of creating functional, safe, and nurturing living environments through efficient planning and resource allocation.

Label: Home and family management
definition: The systematic application of organizational principles and domestic skills to coordinate household operations, encompassing food preparation, housing maintenance, interior design, clothing care, child rearing, and family care, with the objective of creating functional, safe, and nurturing living environments through efficient planning and resource allocation.

Label: Food and drink
definition: The study and practice of selecting, preparing, preserving, and serving edible substances and beverages, focusing on nutritional value, safety, culinary techniques, and the scientific principles underlying food composition and transformation.

Label: Meals and table service
definition: The art and methodology of planning, arranging, and presenting meals, including menu design, portioning, plating aesthetics, and the formal procedures for serving food and beverages at dining tables to enhance the dining experience.

Label: Housing and household equipment
definition: The evaluation, selection, maintenance, and efficient use of residential structures and the mechanical or electronic devices within them, such as appliances and tools, to ensure safety, functionality, and sustainability in domestic settings.

Label: Household utilities
definition: The management and optimization of essential services supplied to a home, including water, electricity, gas, heating, cooling, and sanitation systems, with emphasis on reliability, cost-effectiveness, and environmental impact.

Label: Household furnishings
definition: The selection, arrangement, and care of movable objects used to make a home habitable and aesthetically pleasing, such as furniture, textiles, decorations, and lighting, balancing comfort, style, and practicality.

Label: Sewing, clothing, management of personal and family life
definition: The skills and practices involved in creating, repairing, and maintaining garments through sewing techniques, along with the organization of wardrobe, personal grooming, and daily routines to support individual and family well-being.

Label: Management of public households (institutional housekeeping)
definition: The administration of domestic operations in non-residential settings like hotels, hospitals, or schools, focusing on large-scale cleaning, maintenance, supply logistics, and staff coordination to ensure hygienic and orderly environments.

Label: Housekeeping
definition: The routine tasks and systematic processes for maintaining cleanliness, order, and upkeep within a home, including cleaning, laundry, inventory management, and minor repairs to preserve a sanitary and organized living space.

Label: Child rearing; home care of people with disabilities and illnesses
definition: The practices and principles for nurturing and educating children within a family context, combined with the provision of compassionate, skilled care at home for individuals with disabilities or health conditions, emphasizing emotional support, safety, and developmental needs.

Label: Management and public relations
definition: The systematic coordination of organizational resources, processes, and communication strategies to achieve business objectives, encompassing office administration, accounting practices, general management principles, and the strategic development of organizational image and stakeholder relationships through advertising and public relations initiatives.

Label: Management and auxiliary services
definition: The systematic coordination of organizational resources, processes, and communication strategies to achieve business objectives, encompassing office administration, accounting practices, general management principles, and the strategic development of organizational image and stakeholder relationships through advertising and public relations initiatives.

Label: Office services
definition: The administrative functions and support activities that facilitate the daily operations of an organization, including document management, correspondence handling, scheduling, record keeping, and the maintenance of office equipment and supplies to ensure efficient workflow and communication.

Label: Processes of written communication
definition: The systematic methods and techniques employed in creating, formatting, editing, and distributing written documents within organizational contexts, encompassing business correspondence, report preparation, documentation standards, and the application of professional writing principles to convey information clearly and effectively.

Label: Shorthand
definition: A rapid writing system using abbreviated symbols or characters to represent words, phrases, or sounds, enabling efficient transcription of spoken language in business meetings, dictation, and other professional settings where speed and accuracy in recording information are essential.

Label: Accounting
definition: The systematic recording, analysis, and reporting of financial transactions and information about an economic entity, involving the measurement, processing, and communication of financial data to support decision-making, ensure regulatory compliance, and provide transparency regarding an organization's economic activities and performance.

Label: General management
definition: The comprehensive practice of planning, organizing, directing, and controlling an organization's resources and operations to achieve its objectives, encompassing strategic decision-making, leadership, resource allocation, performance monitoring, and the coordination of various functional areas to ensure organizational effectiveness and efficiency.

Label: Advertising and public relations
definition: The strategic communication disciplines focused on building and maintaining positive relationships between organizations and their stakeholders, involving the creation and dissemination of persuasive messages through paid media channels (advertising) and the management of information flow, reputation, and public perception through earned media and direct engagement (public relations).

Label: Chemical engineering
definition: The branch of engineering that applies physical sciences, chemistry, and life sciences with mathematics and economics to processes that convert raw materials or chemicals into more useful or valuable forms, specializing in the design, operation, and optimization of chemical plants. Distinct from theoretical Chemistry (540).

Label: Chemical engineering and related technologies
definition: The branch of engineering that applies physical sciences, chemistry, and life sciences with mathematics and economics to processes that convert raw materials or chemicals into more useful or valuable forms, specializing in the design, operation, and optimization of chemical plants. Distinct from theoretical Chemistry (540).

Label: Technology of industrial chemicals
definition: The applied science and engineering discipline focused on the large-scale production, processing, and application of chemicals used in manufacturing and industrial processes, including petrochemicals, polymers, fertilizers, acids, alkalis, and specialty chemicals essential for various industries.

Label: Technology of explosives, fuels, related products
definition: The engineering field concerned with the development, production, and application of energetic materials including explosives for mining, construction, and military purposes, as well as various fuels such as gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, and alternative energy sources through refining, synthesis, and combustion optimization processes.

Label: Beverage technology
definition: The specialized application of chemical engineering principles to the production, processing, preservation, and packaging of liquid consumables including alcoholic beverages (beer, wine, spirits), non-alcoholic drinks (soft drinks, juices), and other prepared beverages, focusing on fermentation, carbonation, pasteurization, and quality control.

Label: Food technology
definition: The scientific discipline that applies engineering, chemistry, and microbiology to the processing, preservation, packaging, storage, and distribution of food products, ensuring safety, nutritional value, shelf life, and sensory qualities through techniques such as thermal processing, freezing, drying, and packaging innovations.

Label: Technology of industrial oils, fats, waxes, gases
definition: The engineering specialization dealing with the extraction, refining, modification, and application of lipid-based materials and industrial gases, including vegetable oils, animal fats, petroleum-based lubricants, natural and synthetic waxes, and various industrial gases used in manufacturing, energy, and chemical processes.

Label: Ceramic and allied technologies
definition: The materials engineering field focused on the production, processing, and application of inorganic, non-metallic materials through high-temperature processing, including traditional ceramics (pottery, bricks), advanced ceramics (electronic, biomedical), glass, cement, and refractory materials with specific thermal, electrical, and mechanical properties.

Label: Cleaning, color, coating, related technologies
definition: The applied chemical engineering discipline concerned with surface treatments and modifications, including cleaning agents and processes, dye and pigment production and application, paints, varnishes, protective coatings, adhesives, and surface finishing techniques for industrial and consumer products.

Label: Technology of other organic products
definition: The engineering specialization focused on the production and processing of organic compounds not covered by other specific categories, including pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, cosmetics, fragrances, dyes, plastics, rubber, and other synthetic or naturally derived organic materials through chemical synthesis, extraction, and purification processes.

Label: Metallurgy
definition: The science and technology of metals, encompassing the extraction of metals from their ores, purification, alloying, and processing into useful forms through techniques such as smelting, refining, casting, forging, and heat treatment, with applications in structural materials, electronics, and advanced manufacturing.

Label: Manufacturing
definition: The industrial process of transforming raw materials into finished goods through various mechanical, physical, or chemical operations, encompassing metalworking, wood processing, textile production, paper manufacturing, and the fabrication of products from specific materials using systematic production methods and quality control measures.

Label: Manufacturing
definition: The industrial process of transforming raw materials into finished goods through various mechanical, physical, or chemical operations, encompassing metalworking, wood processing, textile production, paper manufacturing, and the fabrication of products from specific materials using systematic production methods and quality control measures.

Label: Metalworking processes and primary metal products
definition: The industrial techniques and operations involved in shaping, forming, joining, and finishing metals to create primary metal products, including casting, forging, machining, welding, and metal fabrication methods that transform raw metallic materials into semi-finished or finished components.

Label: Iron, steel, other iron alloys
definition: The manufacturing processes and products specifically involving ferrous metals, including the production of iron through smelting, the creation of steel through alloying and heat treatment, and the fabrication of various iron-based alloys with controlled carbon content and other alloying elements for structural, mechanical, and industrial applications.

Label: Nonferrous metals
definition: The industrial processing and product manufacturing involving metals that contain little to no iron, including aluminum, copper, zinc, lead, tin, nickel, and precious metals like gold and silver, with manufacturing methods tailored to their specific physical and chemical properties for applications ranging from electrical components to corrosion-resistant structures.

Label: Lumber processing, wood products, cork
definition: The industrial transformation of harvested timber into usable materials and products, including sawing, planing, drying, and treating wood to create lumber, plywood, engineered wood products, furniture components, and the specialized processing of cork bark for various applications in construction, packaging, and consumer goods.

Label: Leather processing and fur processing
definition: The industrial treatment and transformation of animal hides and skins into durable, flexible materials through processes including tanning, dyeing, and finishing for leather production, and the cleaning, treating, and assembling of animal pelts for fur products, involving chemical treatments and mechanical operations to preserve and enhance natural materials.

Label: Pulp and paper technology
definition: The industrial processes for converting plant fibers, primarily wood, into pulp through mechanical or chemical means, followed by papermaking operations that form, press, dry, and finish the pulp into various paper products, including writing paper, packaging materials, and specialty papers with controlled properties.

Label: Textiles
definition: The manufacturing of flexible materials made through weaving, knitting, crocheting, knotting, or felting natural or synthetic fibers, involving processes from fiber preparation and yarn spinning to fabric formation and finishing treatments that create materials for clothing, furnishings, and industrial applications.

Label: Elastomers and elastomer products
definition: The manufacturing of materials and products from polymers with viscoelastic properties, primarily natural and synthetic rubbers, through processes including compounding, molding, extrusion, and vulcanization to create products that exhibit significant elasticity and resilience, such as tires, seals, gaskets, and flexible components.

Label: Other products of specific kinds of materials
definition: The manufacturing processes and products involving specialized materials not covered by the primary material categories, including ceramics, glass, composites, plastics (excluding elastomers), and advanced materials, with fabrication methods tailored to their unique properties for applications in electronics, construction, medical devices, and specialized industrial components.

Label: Manufacture for specific uses
definition: The specialized production of finished goods designed for particular applications or end-user needs, involving the creation of precision instruments, hardware, household appliances, clothing, printed materials, packaging solutions, and other consumer or industrial products through functional design, material selection, and fabrication techniques tailored to specific requirements.

Label: Manufacture of products for specific uses
definition: The specialized production of finished goods designed for particular applications or end-user needs, involving the creation of precision instruments, hardware, household appliances, clothing, printed materials, packaging solutions, and other consumer or industrial products through functional design, material selection, and fabrication techniques tailored to specific requirements.

Label: Precision instruments and other devices
definition: The manufacture of highly accurate and reliable tools, instruments, and devices used for measurement, control, scientific research, medical applications, or specialized industrial processes, requiring exacting standards of craftsmanship, calibration, and quality control to ensure consistent performance and minimal tolerances.

Label: Small forge work (blacksmithing)
definition: The traditional metalworking craft involving the heating, shaping, and joining of iron and steel through forging techniques using hammers, anvils, and specialized tools to create functional or decorative items such as tools, hardware, architectural elements, and artistic pieces through controlled deformation and heat treatment.

Label: Hardware and household appliances
definition: The production of durable goods and mechanical devices for domestic and commercial use, including tools, fasteners, locks, plumbing fixtures, kitchen equipment, cleaning devices, and climate control systems designed for practical functionality, safety standards, and integration into built environments.

Label: Furnishings and home workshops
definition: The creation of furniture, cabinetry, storage solutions, and interior fixtures along with the tools, equipment, and workspaces designed for domestic woodworking, repair, and creative projects, focusing on ergonomic design, material durability, and spatial optimization for residential environments.

Label: Leather and fur goods, and related products
definition: The craft and industrial processing of animal hides and pelts through tanning, cutting, stitching, and finishing techniques to produce durable goods such as footwear, bags, belts, garments, upholstery, and accessories, utilizing specialized treatments for texture, flexibility, and longevity.

Label: Printing and related activities
definition: The reproduction of text and images through various mechanical and digital processes including typesetting, plate-making, press operation, binding, and finishing to create publications, packaging, labels, and promotional materials with attention to color accuracy, registration, and substrate compatibility.

Label: Clothing and accessories
definition: The design, patterning, cutting, sewing, and finishing of textiles and materials to create wearable items such as garments, footwear, hats, and jewelry, incorporating considerations of fit, fashion, functionality, and fabric properties through both manual and automated production methods.

Label: Other final products, and packaging technology
definition: The manufacture of miscellaneous consumer and industrial goods not covered by other categories, along with the engineering of containers, wrappers, and protective systems for product storage, transportation, and display, focusing on material science, structural integrity, and user interaction.

Label: Construction of buildings
definition: The comprehensive process of erecting structures through systematic assembly of building materials and components to create enclosed spaces for human habitation or use, encompassing foundation work, structural systems, utility installation, interior finishing, and specialized techniques for different construction materials while ensuring safety, durability, and functionality.

Label: Construction of buildings
definition: The comprehensive process of erecting structures through systematic assembly of building materials and components to create enclosed spaces for human habitation or use, encompassing foundation work, structural systems, utility installation, interior finishing, and specialized techniques for different construction materials while ensuring safety, durability, and functionality.

Label: Building materials
definition: The diverse range of substances and products used in construction, including natural materials like wood, stone, and clay, as well as manufactured materials such as concrete, steel, glass, and composites, selected based on properties like strength, durability, thermal performance, and aesthetic qualities to meet structural and functional requirements.

Label: Auxiliary construction practices
definition: Supporting activities and specialized techniques that facilitate the primary construction process, including site preparation, excavation, scaffolding, formwork, temporary structures, material handling, safety protocols, quality control measures, and project management procedures essential for efficient and safe building assembly.

Label: Construction in specific types of materials and for specific purposes
definition: Specialized building methods and techniques tailored to particular material systems or functional requirements, addressing unique properties, assembly methods, and performance characteristics of materials like masonry, steel, concrete, or glass, as well as construction approaches for specialized structures such as industrial facilities, agricultural buildings, or heritage preservation projects.

Label: Wood construction
definition: Building methods and techniques utilizing timber and wood-based products as primary structural and finishing materials, encompassing traditional timber framing, modern platform framing, engineered wood systems, joinery techniques, and specialized approaches for residential, commercial, and heavy timber structures that leverage wood's renewable nature, workability, and aesthetic qualities.

Label: Roof covering
definition: The installation of protective layers and systems on building roofs to provide weatherproofing, thermal insulation, and durability, including materials such as shingles, tiles, metal panels, membranes, and thatch, along with associated components like underlayment, flashing, drainage systems, and ventilation that ensure long-term performance and protection from environmental elements.

Label: Utilities
definition: The installation and integration of essential service systems within buildings, including electrical wiring, plumbing networks, gas lines, telecommunications infrastructure, and data cabling that provide power, water, sanitation, communication, and other fundamental services necessary for building functionality and occupant comfort.

Label: Heating, ventilating, air-conditioning engineering
definition: The design, installation, and maintenance of mechanical systems that regulate indoor environmental conditions, encompassing heating equipment, ventilation networks, air conditioning units, humidity control, air filtration, and energy recovery systems that ensure thermal comfort, indoor air quality, and energy efficiency throughout building spaces.

Label: Detail finishing
definition: The final phase of construction involving precise installation of interior and exterior elements that define a building's aesthetic character and functional completeness, including trim work, cabinetry, flooring, wall finishes, hardware, fixtures, painting, and decorative elements that transform structural spaces into habitable environments with specific visual and tactile qualities.

Label: Arts and recreation
definition: The comprehensive domain encompassing the creation, appreciation, and study of fine and decorative arts, including their philosophical foundations, historical development, and institutional frameworks such as museums, galleries, and educational programs.

Label: Arts
definition: The comprehensive domain encompassing the creation, appreciation, and study of fine and decorative arts, including their philosophical foundations, historical development, and institutional frameworks such as museums, galleries, and educational programs.

Label: The arts
definition: The comprehensive domain encompassing the creation, appreciation, and study of fine and decorative arts, including their philosophical foundations, historical development, and institutional frameworks such as museums, galleries, and educational programs.

Label: Philosophy and theory of fine arts and decorative arts
definition: The systematic inquiry into the fundamental nature, principles, and conceptual frameworks underlying fine and decorative arts, examining questions of aesthetics, meaning, value, interpretation, and the relationship between art, artist, and society.

Label: Miscellany of fine and decorative arts
definition: A diverse collection of materials, writings, and resources related to fine and decorative arts that do not fit into more specific categories, often including anthologies, compilations, general reference works, and varied content spanning multiple aspects of artistic practice and appreciation.

Label: Dictionaries, encyclopedias, concordances of fine and decorative arts
definition: Reference works that systematically organize and define terminology, concepts, artists, movements, and techniques within fine and decorative arts, providing authoritative information through alphabetical arrangements, thematic entries, or cross-referenced indexes for research and study purposes.

Label: Special topics in fine and decorative arts
definition: Focused examinations of specific themes, movements, techniques, or issues within fine and decorative arts that require dedicated study beyond general surveys, often addressing niche subjects, emerging trends, or specialized aspects of artistic practice and theory.

Label: Serial publications of fine and decorative arts
definition: Periodical publications issued in successive parts at regular intervals that document, analyze, and disseminate developments in fine and decorative arts, including journals, magazines, annuals, and ongoing series that provide current research, criticism, and documentation of artistic practice.

Label: Organizations and management of fine and decorative arts
definition: The structural, administrative, and operational aspects of institutions and entities involved with fine and decorative arts, encompassing governance, funding, strategic planning, policy development, and the practical systems that support artistic production, exhibition, and preservation.

Label: Education, research, related topics of fine and decorative arts
definition: The pedagogical methods, academic programs, scholarly investigation, and knowledge dissemination practices specifically focused on fine and decorative arts, including curriculum development, teaching methodologies, research methodologies, and the transmission of artistic skills and understanding.

Label: Galleries, museums, private collections of fine and decorative arts
definition: Institutions and personal assemblages dedicated to the acquisition, preservation, exhibition, and interpretation of fine and decorative arts objects, serving as repositories of cultural heritage and spaces for public engagement with artistic works through curated displays and educational programming.

Label: History, geographic treatment, biography
definition: The chronological documentation and analysis of developments in fine and decorative arts across time periods and regions, including the study of artistic movements, regional variations, cultural contexts, and the lives and careers of individual artists and artisans.

Label: Area planning and landscape architecture
definition: The professional practice and design discipline focused on the intentional arrangement and modification of outdoor spaces, encompassing both the strategic organization of land use and the aesthetic and functional design of landscapes. This field integrates principles from urban planning, environmental science, and design to create harmonious, sustainable, and purposeful outdoor environments, addressing both large-scale civic planning and detailed landscape composition.

Label: Area planning and landscape architecture
definition: The professional practice and design discipline focused on the intentional arrangement and modification of outdoor spaces, encompassing both the strategic organization of land use and the aesthetic and functional design of landscapes. This field integrates principles from urban planning, environmental science, and design to create harmonious, sustainable, and purposeful outdoor environments, addressing both large-scale civic planning and detailed landscape composition.

Label: Area planning (civic art)
definition: The strategic organization and design of public spaces and urban areas to enhance aesthetic quality, functionality, and community well-being. This aspect of planning focuses on the artistic and spatial arrangement of civic elements such as plazas, parks, streetscapes, and public buildings, aiming to create visually cohesive and socially vibrant urban environments that reflect cultural values and improve quality of life.

Label: Landscape architecture (Landscape design)
definition: The art and science of designing outdoor environments, ranging from gardens and parks to campuses and corporate landscapes. This discipline involves the creative arrangement of natural and built elementsincluding landforms, vegetation, water, and structuresto achieve aesthetic, ecological, and functional outcomes, balancing human needs with environmental stewardship through site analysis, conceptual design, and detailed implementation planning.

Label: Landscape architecture of trafficways
definition: The specialized design of transportation corridorssuch as roads, highways, bridges, and pedestrian pathwaysto integrate them harmoniously into the surrounding landscape. This practice addresses safety, aesthetics, and environmental impact by incorporating vegetation, grading, drainage systems, and visual buffers, aiming to reduce the disruptive effects of infrastructure while enhancing the travel experience and ecological connectivity.

Label: Water features in landscape architecture
definition: The intentional incorporation of aquatic elementssuch as ponds, streams, fountains, waterfalls, and wetlandsinto landscape design to achieve aesthetic, ecological, and functional purposes. These features can provide visual interest, auditory ambiance, habitat for wildlife, stormwater management, and microclimate regulation, requiring careful planning for hydrology, maintenance, and integration with surrounding landforms and vegetation.

Label: Woody plants in landscape architecture
definition: The strategic use of trees, shrubs, and other perennial plants with woody stems in landscape design to provide structure, shade, seasonal interest, and ecological benefits. This involves selecting, placing, and maintaining species based on factors like growth habit, hardiness, aesthetic qualities (e.g., foliage, bark, form), and functional roles such as screening, windbreaking, or soil stabilization, contributing to long-term landscape composition and sustainability.

Label: Herbaceous plants in landscape architecture
definition: The design application of non-woody plantsincluding perennials, annuals, grasses, and groundcoversto add color, texture, seasonal variation, and ecological diversity to landscapes. These plants are often used in borders, meadows, or mass plantings to create visual layers, support pollinators, and manage soil erosion, requiring consideration of bloom cycles, maintenance needs, and compatibility with site conditions and design themes.

Label: Structures in landscape architecture
definition: The integration of built elementssuch as pavilions, pergolas, walls, steps, lighting fixtures, and furnitureinto outdoor spaces to enhance functionality, define areas, and complement natural features. These structures provide shelter, circulation, seating, and visual anchors, designed with materials, scales, and styles that harmonize with the landscape context and support human activities while enduring environmental exposure.

Label: Landscape design of cemeteries
definition: The thoughtful planning and arrangement of burial grounds to create serene, respectful, and sustainable environments for memorialization and contemplation. This involves layout of pathways, gravesites, and communal areas; selection of vegetation for symbolism, maintenance, and seasonal interest; and integration of features like mausoleums, markers, and water elements, balancing practical needs with aesthetic and emotional considerations.

Label: Natural landscapes
definition: Outdoor environments shaped primarily by ecological processes and natural forces, with minimal human alteration. In landscape architecture, this concept involves the preservation, restoration, or emulation of such settingslike forests, meadows, wetlands, or coastlinesto maintain biodiversity, ecosystem services, and scenic beauty, often through techniques that mimic natural patterns, use native species, and reduce intervention while accommodating human access and appreciation.

Label: Architecture
definition: The art and science of designing and constructing buildings and other physical structures, encompassing the integration of aesthetic principles, functional requirements, structural engineering, and material selection to create habitable spaces that serve human needs while reflecting cultural values and historical contexts.

Label: Architecture
definition: The art and science of designing and constructing buildings and other physical structures, encompassing the integration of aesthetic principles, functional requirements, structural engineering, and material selection to create habitable spaces that serve human needs while reflecting cultural values and historical contexts.

Label: Architectural materials and structural elements
definition: The physical components and substances used in building construction, including their properties, applications, and assembly methods, such as stone, wood, concrete, steel, glass, and composite materials, along with foundational systems, load-bearing structures, roofing, and other essential building parts that determine durability, form, and performance.

Label: Architecture from earliest times to c. 300
definition: The architectural practices and built environments from prehistoric periods through ancient civilizations up to approximately 300 CE, characterized by early human shelters, monumental structures like pyramids and ziggurats, classical Greek and Roman temples, aqueducts, and amphitheaters, reflecting technological innovations in masonry, urban planning, and religious or civic expression.

Label: Architecture from c. 300 to 1399
definition: The architectural developments from late antiquity through the medieval period, spanning Byzantine, Romanesque, and Gothic styles, with features such as domed churches, fortified castles, monastic complexes, and cathedrals employing pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and stained glass, often serving religious, defensive, or feudal societal roles across Europe, Asia, and other regions.

Label: Architecture from 1400
definition: The architectural evolution from the Renaissance onward, including Renaissance, Baroque, Neoclassical, Modern, and contemporary movements, marked by a revival of classical principles, experimentation with form and function, industrialization influences, and innovations like steel-frame construction, leading to skyscrapers, avant-garde designs, and sustainable building practices that address modern societal needs.

Label: Public structures
definition: Buildings and facilities designed for communal use and civic functions, such as government buildings, libraries, museums, theaters, transportation hubs, sports arenas, and parks, prioritizing accessibility, durability, and symbolic representation to serve broad public interests, foster social interaction, and support urban infrastructure.

Label: Buildings for religious and related purposes
definition: Structures dedicated to spiritual practices, worship, and religious ceremonies, including churches, temples, mosques, synagogues, shrines, and monasteries, often featuring symbolic geometries, sacred art, and acoustical designs to facilitate ritual activities, community gathering, and transcendental experiences aligned with specific faith traditions.

Label: Buildings for educational and research purposes
definition: Facilities constructed to support learning, teaching, and scholarly inquiry, such as schools, universities, laboratories, libraries, and research centers, designed with classrooms, lecture halls, specialized equipment, and collaborative spaces to optimize knowledge acquisition, experimentation, and intellectual exchange in academic or scientific contexts.

Label: Residential and related buildings
definition: Structures intended for human habitation and domestic life, including houses, apartments, dormitories, hotels, and retirement homes, focusing on livability, privacy, comfort, and safety through layouts, amenities, and environmental controls that accommodate daily routines, family dynamics, and personal well-being.

Label: Design and decoration of structures and accessories
definition: The artistic and functional aspects of architectural embellishment and interior detailing, involving elements like ornamentation, color schemes, furniture, lighting, and landscaping to enhance aesthetic appeal, cultural expression, and user experience, often integrating craftsmanship, stylistic trends, and material finishes to complement structural forms.

Label: Sculpture, ceramics and metalwork
definition: The artistic discipline encompassing three-dimensional works created through processes like carving, modeling, casting, and assembling, along with closely associated decorative arts that involve similar material manipulation and aesthetic principles, including ceramics, art metalwork, and numismatics.

Label: Sculpture and related arts
definition: The artistic discipline encompassing three-dimensional works created through processes like carving, modeling, casting, and assembling, along with closely associated decorative arts that involve similar material manipulation and aesthetic principles, including ceramics, art metalwork, and numismatics.

Label: Processes, forms, subjects of sculpture
definition: The technical methods employed in creating three-dimensional artworks, such as carving, modeling, casting, and assemblage; the resulting physical configurations including freestanding, relief, and kinetic forms; and the thematic content ranging from figurative representation to abstract expression that artists explore through sculptural media.

Label: Sculpture from earliest times to c. 500, sculpture of non-literate peoples
definition: Three-dimensional artistic works created during prehistoric periods through approximately 500 CE, encompassing ancient civilizations' sculptural traditions as well as the material culture of societies without written records, characterized by ritual objects, votive figures, architectural elements, and artifacts that reveal cultural beliefs and practices through form and material.

Label: Greek, Etruscan, Roman sculpture
definition: The sculptural traditions of classical antiquity spanning approximately the 8th century BCE to the 5th century CE, distinguished by Greek emphasis on idealized human form and mathematical proportions, Etruscan funerary art and terracotta works, and Roman portraiture, historical reliefs, and architectural sculpture that synthesized and expanded upon earlier Mediterranean influences.

Label: Sculpture from ca 500 to 1399
definition: Three-dimensional artistic production during the medieval period, characterized by religious iconography serving liturgical and didactic functions, evolving stylistic approaches from early Christian sarcophagi to Romanesque architectural sculpture and Gothic cathedral programs, with materials ranging from ivory and precious metals to stone and wood across European, Byzantine, and Islamic traditions.

Label: Sculpture from 1400
definition: The development of three-dimensional art from the Renaissance onward, marked by renewed interest in classical forms and humanist ideals, technical innovations in bronze casting and marble carving, evolving movements through Baroque dynamism, Neoclassical restraint, Modernist abstraction, and contemporary conceptual approaches that expanded sculpture's materials, scales, and relationship to space.

Label: Carving and carvings
definition: The subtractive sculptural technique of removing material from a solid block using tools like chisels, knives, or abrasives, and the resulting works in media such as wood, stone, ivory, or bone that range from small-scale decorative objects to monumental architectural elements, distinguished by the craftsman's direct engagement with material resistance and grain.

Label: Numismatics and sigillography
definition: The scholarly study of coins, medals, and tokens (numismatics) and seals, signets, and their impressions (sigillography) as historical documents and artistic objects, examining their design, production, iconography, metallurgy, and circulation to understand economic systems, political authority, cultural exchange, and artistic development across civilizations.

Label: Ceramic arts
definition: The creation of objects from clay and other ceramic materials through forming techniques like throwing, coiling, or molding, followed by firing to achieve permanence, encompassing functional pottery, decorative vessels, sculptural forms, and architectural elements that demonstrate technical mastery of glazes, surface treatments, and kiln technologies across cultures and historical periods.

Label: Art metalwork
definition: The artistic manipulation of metals through techniques including forging, casting, chasing, repouss, and engraving to create objects ranging from jewelry and liturgical vessels to architectural elements and sculptural forms, distinguished by the material's malleability, luster, and durability that allows for both intricate detail and structural strength in decorative and functional works.

Label: Graphic arts and decorative arts
definition: The visual arts focused on two-dimensional creation and applied design, encompassing drawing, perspective, communication design, and the crafting of decorative objects for interiors, including textiles, glasswork, and furniture.

Label: Graphic arts
definition: The visual arts focused on two-dimensional creation and applied design, encompassing drawing, perspective, communication design, and the crafting of decorative objects for interiors, including textiles, glasswork, and furniture.

Label: Drawing and drawings
definition: The fundamental visual art practice of creating images, forms, and compositions using various mark-making tools and techniques on surfaces, serving as both preparatory studies and finished artworks that capture observation, imagination, and expression through line, tone, and texture.

Label: Perspective in drawing
definition: The systematic technique in visual representation that creates the illusion of three-dimensional space and depth on a two-dimensional surface through mathematical principles governing the apparent size, position, and convergence of objects relative to the viewer's vantage point.

Label: Drawing and drawings by subject
definition: The classification and study of drawings organized according to their thematic content, including portraiture, landscape, still life, figure drawing, architectural rendering, and other specific motifs that determine compositional approaches and representational techniques.

Label: Communication design and visual design (proposed)
definition: The applied visual art discipline concerned with strategically organizing visual elementstypography, imagery, color, and layoutto effectively convey information, ideas, and messages for specific audiences and purposes across various media and contexts.

Label: Decorative arts
definition: The creation of ornamental and functional objects that enhance interior environments through skilled craftsmanship in materials such as textiles, glass, metal, and wood, prioritizing aesthetic appeal and practical utility in domestic and architectural settings.

Label: Textile arts
definition: The artistic practice involving the design, creation, and manipulation of fibers and fabrics through techniques like weaving, embroidery, knitting, and dyeing to produce decorative and functional textiles for interior applications, clothing, and artistic expression.

Label: Interior decoration
definition: The art of enhancing and organizing interior spaces through the selection and arrangement of decorative elementsincluding furniture, textiles, lighting, color schemes, and accessoriesto create aesthetically pleasing, functional, and harmonious environments.

Label: Glass
definition: The artistic medium involving the manipulation of molten or solid glass through techniques such as blowing, casting, cutting, and etching to create decorative objects, vessels, windows, and architectural elements that utilize transparency, color, and light transmission for aesthetic effect.

Label: Furniture and accessories
definition: The design and creation of movable objects that support human activities within interior spaces, including seating, storage, tables, and decorative items, combining functional requirements with artistic expression through form, material, and craftsmanship.

Label: Painting
definition: The artistic practice of applying pigment to a surface to create images, encompassing both the process of creation and the resulting artworks, involving techniques of color use, symbolic representation, and the depiction of subjects ranging from human figures and nature to religious and genre scenes across historical and geographic contexts.

Label: Painting and paintings
definition: The artistic practice of applying pigment to a surface to create images, encompassing both the process of creation and the resulting artworks, involving techniques of color use, symbolic representation, and the depiction of subjects ranging from human figures and nature to religious and genre scenes across historical and geographic contexts.

Label: Techniques, procedures, apparatus, equipment, materials, forms
definition: The methods, processes, tools, and physical substances employed in the creation of paintings, including brushwork, glazing, impasto, fresco, oil painting, watercolor, acrylics, canvas preparation, easels, palettes, and the various supports and media that constitute the technical foundation of the painter's craft.

Label: Color
definition: The visual perceptual property derived from the spectrum of light interacting with pigments, encompassing hue, saturation, value, and temperature, which painters manipulate to create mood, establish composition, represent light and shadow, and convey symbolic meaning within their artworks.

Label: Symbolism, allegory, mythology, legend
definition: The use of visual elements, figures, and narratives to represent abstract ideas, moral concepts, or cultural stories beyond their literal appearance, where paintings employ symbolic objects, allegorical personifications, mythological scenes, or legendary tales to convey deeper philosophical, religious, or social meanings.

Label: Genre paintings
definition: Paintings that depict scenes from everyday life, ordinary people engaged in common activities, domestic settings, markets, taverns, and other aspects of contemporary social existence, focusing on realistic representation of non-aristocratic subjects and mundane moments rather than historical, religious, or mythological themes.

Label: Religion
definition: Paintings created for devotional purposes, liturgical settings, or religious instruction that depict sacred narratives, divine figures, saints, biblical events, miracles, and spiritual concepts, serving to inspire faith, communicate theological ideas, and decorate places of worship across various religious traditions.

Label: Human figures
definition: The artistic representation of the human form in painting, encompassing portraiture, figure studies, anatomical accuracy, gesture, expression, and the depiction of people in various states of activity, emotion, and social interaction, from individual likenesses to groups in narrative contexts.

Label: Nature, architectural subjects and cityscapes, other specific subjects
definition: Paintings focused on non-human elements of the visual world, including landscapes, seascapes, skies, flora, fauna, geological formations, buildings, urban environments, interior spaces, still lifes of objects, and other specific visual subjects that constitute the setting, background, or primary focus of artistic representation.

Label: History, geographic treatment, biography
definition: Paintings that document, commemorate, or interpret historical events, political developments, military conflicts, social transformations, geographical locations, regional characteristics, or the lives and achievements of significant individuals, serving as visual records and interpretations of temporal and spatial human experience.

Label: Printmaking and prints
definition: The artistic discipline encompassing both the creation of multiple impressions or images through various transfer techniques and the resulting artworks themselves, involving processes where ink is applied to a prepared surface and transferred to paper or another material to produce editions of identical or similar images.

Label: Printmaking and prints
definition: The artistic discipline encompassing both the creation of multiple impressions or images through various transfer techniques and the resulting artworks themselves, involving processes where ink is applied to a prepared surface and transferred to paper or another material to produce editions of identical or similar images.

Label: Relief processes (block printing)
definition: A printmaking technique where the image is created by carving away the non-printing areas of a block material such as wood, linoleum, or rubber, leaving the raised design surface to receive ink that transfers to paper when pressure is applied, producing prints with distinct textural qualities and bold graphic lines.

Label: Lithographic processes (planographic processes)
definition: A printmaking method based on the chemical principle that oil and water repel each other, where the image is drawn with greasy materials on a flat stone or metal plate, treated with chemical solutions to fix the design, then inked and printed, allowing for subtle tonal variations and fluid drawing qualities distinct from relief or intaglio techniques.

Label: Chromolithography and serigraphy
definition: Two distinct color printing methods: chromolithography involves creating multi-color lithographic prints through successive applications of different colored inks using separate stones or plates for each hue, while serigraphy (screen printing) employs a mesh screen with stencils to push ink through open areas onto the printing surface, both enabling vibrant, layered color reproduction in printed artworks.

Label: Metal engraving
definition: An intaglio printmaking technique where lines are incised directly into a metal plate using a sharp tool called a burin or graver, creating grooves that hold ink which transfers to paper under high pressure, producing prints characterized by precise, crisp lines with varying thickness and distinctive swelling and tapering effects based on the engraver's pressure and tool manipulation.

Label: Mezzotinting, aquatinting, and related processes
definition: Intaglio techniques specialized for creating tonal effects rather than linear designs: mezzotint achieves rich velvety blacks and subtle gradations by roughening the entire plate surface then smoothing areas to create lighter tones, while aquatint creates textured areas resembling watercolor washes through acid biting of resin-dusted plates, with related processes including soft-ground etching and crayon manner for additional tonal and textural variations.

Label: Etching and drypoint
definition: Two intaglio methods where lines are created through different approaches: etching involves drawing through an acid-resistant ground on a metal plate then exposing it to acid that bites the exposed lines, allowing for fluid, spontaneous drawing qualities, while drypoint creates lines by scratching directly into the plate with a hard-pointed needle, producing a characteristic burr that yields soft, velvety lines distinct from the cleaner grooves of engraving or etched lines.

Label: Prints
definition: The physical artworks produced through printmaking processes, characterized by their existence as multiple impressions from the same matrix, each considered an original work of art rather than a reproduction, with variations occurring through different inkings, paper types, or intentional alterations by the artist during the printing process.

Label: Photography, computer art, film, video
definition: The broad domain encompassing all artistic practices that utilize technology to capture, create, and manipulate still or moving images, including traditional photographic methods, digital art generation, and the crafts of filmmaking and video production.

Label: Photography, computer art, cinematography, videography
definition: The broad domain encompassing all artistic practices that utilize technology to capture, create, and manipulate still or moving images, including traditional photographic methods, digital art generation, and the crafts of filmmaking and video production.

Label: Techniques, procedures, apparatus, equipment, materials
definition: The practical methodologies, step-by-step processes, tools, devices, and physical substances employed in the creation, capture, and manipulation of images and moving pictures, covering everything from camera operation and lighting setups to software algorithms and chemical developers.

Label: Metallic salt processes
definition: A family of historical and alternative photographic printing techniques where light-sensitive compounds containing silver or other metal salts (such as platinum, palladium, or iron) are used to create permanent images on paper or other substrates, known for their tonal richness and archival stability.

Label: Pigment processes of printing
definition: Photographic printing methods that utilize colored pigments or dyes suspended in a binder, rather than metallic particles, to form the final image, including processes like gum bichromate, carbon transfer, and Fresson printing, which offer extensive control over color and texture.

Label: Computer art (digital art)
definition: The creation of visual artwork primarily through the use of digital computers, software, and algorithms, encompassing generative art, digital painting, 3D modeling, fractal art, and other forms where the computer is an essential tool or medium for artistic expression.

Label: Cinematography and videography
definition: The art and technology of capturing moving images, with cinematography focusing on the artistic and technical aspects of filmmaking for cinema (including lighting, camera movement, and film stock), and videography typically referring to the electronic capture of motion pictures for television, events, or digital media.

Label: Specific fields and special kinds of photography
definition: Specialized photographic practices defined by their subject matter, technique, or application, such as aerial photography, macro photography, photojournalism, scientific photography, portrait photography, and landscape photography, each with distinct methodologies and purposes.

Label: Photographic images
definition: The final visual products created through photographic processes, encompassing prints, negatives, slides, and digital files, studied as artistic objects, historical documents, or cultural artifacts, including their composition, preservation, interpretation, and presentation.

Label: Music
definition: The art form consisting of organized sound and silence, expressed through vocal and instrumental performance, encompassing general musical principles, specific forms, and the study of instruments ranging from keyboards and strings to wind and percussion.

Label: Music
definition: The art form consisting of organized sound and silence, expressed through vocal and instrumental performance, encompassing general musical principles, specific forms, and the study of instruments ranging from keyboards and strings to wind and percussion.

Label: General principles and musical forms
definition: The fundamental concepts, theories, and structural frameworks that govern musical composition and performance, including elements such as harmony, melody, rhythm, and form, as well as established musical genres and compositional structures that have evolved across cultures and historical periods.

Label: Vocal music
definition: Musical compositions and performances that primarily feature the human voice as the central expressive medium, encompassing solo and ensemble singing across various traditions, styles, and cultural contexts, where vocal technique, text setting, and breath control are essential components.

Label: Music for single voices
definition: Musical works specifically composed for individual vocal performers, focusing on the technical and expressive capabilities of solo singers, including art songs, arias, and other repertoire that highlights the unique qualities of a single voice without the blending or harmonic complexity of vocal ensembles.

Label: Instruments and Instrumental ensembles and their music
definition: The study and practice of musical instruments, both individually and in combination, including the construction, technique, and repertoire associated with instrumental performance, as well as the specific musical works composed for various ensemble configurations from duos to full orchestras.

Label: Ensembles with only one instrument per part
definition: Musical groups in which each instrumental part is performed by a single player rather than multiple players on the same part, creating transparent textures where individual instrumental lines remain distinct, as found in chamber music settings such as string quartets, wind quintets, and other small ensemble formations.

Label: Keyboard, mechanical, electrophonic, percussion instruments
definition: A category of musical instruments that produce sound through keys being pressed (keyboards), mechanical action (such as music boxes), electronic generation or amplification (electrophonic), or being struck, shaken, or scraped (percussion), encompassing diverse sound production methods from hammers striking strings to electronic oscillators and resonant surfaces.

Label: Stringed instruments (chordophones)
definition: Musical instruments that produce sound primarily through vibrating strings, which may be plucked, bowed, or struck, with pitch controlled by string length, tension, and thickness, including families such as lutes, violins, guitars, harps, and pianos (when considering their string vibration mechanism).

Label: Wind instruments (aerophones)
definition: Musical instruments that produce sound through the vibration of air columns, typically by blowing air through or across the instrument, with pitch controlled by the length of the air column and the player's embouchure, including woodwinds (flutes, clarinets, oboes) and brass instruments (trumpets, trombones, horns).

Label: Sports, games and entertainment
definition: The diverse range of activities that provide amusement, competition, and leisure through structured engagement, encompassing both artistic performances for public enjoyment and organized physical or mental pursuits that offer entertainment and personal fulfillment.

Label: Recreational arts and performing arts
definition: The diverse range of activities that provide amusement, competition, and leisure through structured engagement, encompassing both artistic performances for public enjoyment and organized physical or mental pursuits that offer entertainment and personal fulfillment.

Label: Public performances
definition: Live presentations before an audience where performers engage in artistic or entertaining acts, including concerts, theatrical productions, dance recitals, comedy shows, and other staged events designed for communal viewing and shared experience.

Label: Stage presentations
definition: Formal theatrical productions performed on a designated platform before an audience, involving scripted dialogue, character portrayal, and dramatic narrative, typically encompassing plays, musicals, operas, and other scripted performances with defined roles and structured storytelling.

Label: Indoor games and amusements
definition: Structured recreational activities conducted within enclosed spaces that provide entertainment through rule-based play, including board games, card games, puzzles, and other pastimes that emphasize social interaction and mental engagement rather than physical exertion.

Label: Indoor games of skill
definition: Recreational activities conducted indoors that require the development and application of specific abilities, techniques, or strategic thinking to achieve success, such as billiards, darts, table tennis, chess, and other games where proficiency is gained through practice and mastery of particular competencies.

Label: Games of chance
definition: Recreational activities where outcomes are determined primarily by random factors rather than skill or strategy, including gambling games like roulette, slot machines, lotteries, and dice games that involve wagering on uncertain results governed by probability.

Label: Athletic and outdoor sports and games
definition: Physical activities conducted in open-air environments that involve structured competition, physical exertion, and the development of athletic abilities, including team sports, individual competitions, and recreational games that utilize natural or constructed outdoor spaces for their execution.

Label: Aquatic sports and air sports
definition: Physical activities that take place in or on water bodies or within the atmosphere, requiring specialized equipment and techniques for movement through these elements, including swimming, diving, sailing, surfing, skydiving, paragliding, and other sports that utilize aquatic or aerial environments as their primary medium.

Label: Equestrian sports and animal racing
definition: Competitive activities involving the partnership between humans and animals, particularly horses, where the animal's speed, agility, or performance is central to the competition, including horse racing, show jumping, dressage, polo, and other events that feature trained animals as primary participants in structured contests.

Label: Fishing, hunting, shooting
definition: Outdoor pursuits that involve the pursuit, capture, or targeting of wildlife or inanimate targets using specialized equipment and techniques, including angling for fish, tracking and taking game animals, and marksmanship activities that test precision and skill with projectile weapons in natural settings.

Label: Literature
definition: The comprehensive interdisciplinary field encompassing both creative literary expression and the systematic study of persuasive communication, integrating the analysis of imaginative written works with the examination of rhetorical techniques, critical methodologies, and theoretical frameworks that shape literary traditions and discourse practices across diverse cultural contexts.

Label: Literature, rhetoric and criticism
definition: The comprehensive interdisciplinary field encompassing both creative literary expression and the systematic study of persuasive communication, integrating the analysis of imaginative written works with the examination of rhetorical techniques, critical methodologies, and theoretical frameworks that shape literary traditions and discourse practices across diverse cultural contexts.

Label: Literature (Belles-lettres) and rhetoric
definition: The comprehensive interdisciplinary field encompassing both creative literary expression and the systematic study of persuasive communication, integrating the analysis of imaginative written works with the examination of rhetorical techniques, critical methodologies, and theoretical frameworks that shape literary traditions and discourse practices across diverse cultural contexts.

Label: Philosophy and theory
definition: The foundational inquiry into the nature, purpose, and principles of literary creation and rhetorical practice, examining fundamental questions about aesthetic value, meaning, interpretation, and the relationship between language, thought, and reality within literary and rhetorical traditions.

Label: Miscellany
definition: A collection of diverse literary and rhetorical materials that do not fit into more specific categories, including anthologies of varied content, compilations of assorted writings, and works that combine multiple forms or approaches without a unified thematic or methodological focus.

Label: Dictionaries, encyclopedias, concordances
definition: Reference works that systematically organize and present information about literary and rhetorical subjects, including specialized lexicons defining terminology, comprehensive compendiums of knowledge about authors and works, and analytical tools that index and cross-reference textual elements across literary corpora.

Label: Serial publications
definition: Periodically issued works in literary and rhetorical studies, including academic journals, literary magazines, annual reviews, and continuing series that present ongoing research, criticism, creative works, or scholarly discussions through regular installments over time.

Label: Organizations and management
definition: The institutional structures, administrative frameworks, and professional associations that support literary and rhetorical activities, including academic departments, research centers, professional societies, funding bodies, and the systematic coordination of resources for literary scholarship and education.

Label: Education, research, related topics
definition: The pedagogical approaches, scholarly investigation methods, and associated practices involved in teaching literary and rhetorical studies, encompassing curriculum development, instructional techniques, academic research methodologies, and the dissemination of knowledge through educational and scholarly channels.

Label: Rhetoric and collections of literary texts from more than two literatures
definition: The study of persuasive communication techniques alongside anthologies that bring together literary works from multiple cultural traditions, examining both the principles of effective discourse and comparative selections that represent diverse literary heritages beyond binary cultural comparisons.

Label: History, description, critical appraisal of more than two literatures
definition: The comprehensive examination of literary traditions across multiple cultures, involving chronological analysis of development, systematic characterization of features and movements, and evaluative assessment of artistic merit and cultural significance within a broad comparative framework.

Label: American literature in English
